subject: Reno in 2011
event:
The news is all over the fannish grapevine -- Seattle has withdrawn its bid to host the World Science Fiction Convention in 2011.  Evidently they lost their facilities.

Reno was their only announced competition for the Seattle bid.  Since the filing deadline has passed, and only Seattle and Reno had filed, it looks as though we'll be going to Reno in 2011.  

Works for me.  I have never been to Reno, but they have a very experienced veteran committee, and facilities superior to those Seattle was offering, so it should be a good con.  (Knock wood.  One really never knows about these things).

I am less sanguine about this year's Montreal worldcon.  With their hotels scattered halfway to hell and gone, Montreal will be even more spread out than last year's Denver con.
Wear comfortable shoes.

comments.article:
Yes, I was surprised that Seattle withdrew, and a conspiratorial part of me wonders at the timing... probably nothing.

Linda actually loved Vegas (despite her misgivings) when we were there following the Anaheim Worldcon, so Reno sounds kind of tempting.

There's no Deep Conspiracy about why Seattle announced its withdrawal yesterday.  Yesterday was the filing deadline to be on the ballot for the 2011 site selection.  The Seattle committee was working through yesterday to try and put together some sort of plan that would allow them to go forward, but in the end there was no viable 2011 bid they could present.  They hadn't said anything sooner because they were scrambling to try and work something out, possibly for other dates in the acceptable range.  Time ran out, so they called their competition and told them the news, then announced that they were withdrawing.

There is no way in hell I'm going to Reno in August.

(Reno in August sounds like a good facsimile of hell to me, frankly. I don't do Hot.)

Reno's not that bad, really. It's not as hot as Vegas, and it's drier.

Vegas in August is Hell, OTOH.
Montreal may be like San Francisco, spread out but in a city friendly to pedestrians.
Montreal isn't so bad... I did my honeymoon there.  Friendly people, and the public transit is very good.
I have to echo that.  My wife and I had our honeymoon there and its really nice walking around there and their subway system is SOOO much better than what I'm used to (and I grew up in NYC).

Reno is a little Las Vegas without the heat depending on where you are coming from.  You can expect 75-90 degrees during the day but it cools off at night unlike Las Vegas Hell.  Just thought I would share.
comments.subject: Reno

comments.article: Maybe the facilities in Seattle aren't adequate, but the blistering heat of Reno in August cannot even compare to the cool, sea breeze you get off the Puget Sound in Seattle. In general, a much more pleasant destination than Reno...

SWEET!!!!
I'm sorry, but I appear to be the only person psyched about the likely new venue. It's closer to me, I would actually be able to go, as opposed to the Seattle venue, and my husband can come along and have something to do.
And the heat isn't that bad, just drink lots of water and wear natural-fiber clothing. TAda, good times!

Furthermore, it's pretty near Tahoe if you want to take a couple extra days.

Or heck, go up to Donner Lake and do Cannibal Banquets.

Speaking as someone 15 minutes from Seattle, :( .

But hey, a good event's a good event.

Reno doesn't have blistering heat *giggles* I live in Carson City (30 minutes away) and really, it's not that bad :P Besides if you get really hot you should just run up the mountain and jump in Lake Tahoe ;)

comments.upictitle: Xray Is As Xray Does: horns
comments.article:
Bummed about Seattle but really excited about Reno. See, my family has a house near Donner Lake and I love the area.

For those worried about heat -- Reno is EMPHATICALLY NOT Las Vegas. It's not that hot in the summer (it's certainly not Vegas or Phoenix or even Fresno hot) and the only real problem is the dehydration factor.

So, yeah, I'm bummed I won't get to see my non-fandom Seattle-area friends, but I'm pretty interested to see what the Reno committee comes up with. :)

I have actually walked around Reno's facilities. It will be nice and compact if you get a room at the HQ hotel (the Atlantis), which is connected to the convention center by a skywalk so you don't have to go outside or even go through the casino floor (take elevator to second floor, walk through the arcade, and you're on your way). It's not going to be so great for people at the main overflow hotel, which is roughly a kilometer (2/3 mile) away. I like walking, and regularly walk multiple kilometers per day for my health; however, I don't think I'd want to walk between the Peppermill and the Atlantis/Convention Center complex in 40 degree C (about 104 F) heat.

Last August, I did an report after a visit I paid to the site on the equivalent weekend to the one Reno is bidding.

I used to live in Reno and its a nice little city. There's really no traffic and there are a lot of neat things in the area like the Bowling and Auto museums, casinos of course, and Lake Tahoe and all its amenities.

There are also sights off the beaten path like Virginia City (the Comstock Lode) where you can tour old mines and Pyramid Lake/Pyramid Reservation, a place I highly recommend both for the spectacular beauty of the lake and its unique rock formations, and for the nice Paiute museum at the south end of the lake in Nixon.

Flying directly into Reno is expensive but flying in Sacramento and driving the hour and a half to Reno is usually a lot cheaper if you were going to rent a car anyway. Sacramento is also a very interesting place for tourism with the Old Town shopping and the train museum.

comments.upictitle: Jenna: Sugar and spice and all that
comments.article:
But the bad thing about this is that unless I get signed by then (which I suppose is not ENTIRELY out of the realm of possibility) and my publisher loves me enough to send me there's not CHANCE that I can make it to WorldCon in Reno :( I was really hoping for the chance to go.

...

You should do NorWesCon up here sometime soon. I promise I wouldn't squeal TOO loudly!

Publishers send writers to Worldcon? Really?

The writer I was married to for mumblty-mumble years paid out of pocket to go. No publisher sent him. Of course, having gone to Worldcon, sat down with editors to discuss projects, and delivered books as a result, it ended up paying well in excess of what it cost to go.

And it was deductible as research.

Heck, I'm a lowly government scribe, and even I manage to scratch up enough to go. If you're serious about being a professional in this field, you're nuts to skip it.

Still hitting the cons, eh? I hear tell that pens and paper are portable nowadays. Laptops, too.

Kidding of course. I'm certain you're still working on the series that made you relevant in the first place. You just don't want to tell us anything about it.
comments.subject: you pros and your cons

comments.article:
OK, let me explain something to you about professionals going to major conventions and WorldCons:

It's part of our business. We go to conventions to promote our works, to met with editors/publishers/other writers. To meet fans, to attend panels and other events that enlighten us, bring us closer to the world of SF, which, for most writers, who work alone and are mostly self-employed, is sometimes hard to access when your peers are scattered across the planet.

The fact that at the end of the day a pro might have a nice dinner, a few drinks, hang out with friends, after spending 10 hours working is no different than the guys at the plant having a few beers at a tavern before going home to the wife and kids.

When a writer agrees, often years in advance, that he/she will attend a convention, especially as a GoH, the committee is counting on that pro to attend and boost attendance.

George had been nominated and won countless awards in the field since he published his first story in the early 70's. He won his first Hugo in 1975. He started writing "AGoT" almost 20 years later.

Why would he tell you anything about it? Why should he? He's said countless times it will be done when it is done. If you want to hear a sample reading, you could go to a convention and hear George read, but wait, by your standards, George shouldn't attend conventions at all, so I guess you're out of luck in getting a 'preview'.

So take your lame snark elsewhere, it ain't going to be appreciated around here.

Idiot.
comments.subject: Re: you pros and your cons
Re: you pros and your cons
Re: you pros and your cons
Re: you pros and your cons

comments.article:
Montreal is less spread out than Denver: 3 hotels across the street from the Convention Center (Denver had 1), and the party hotel is closer.

Montreal is more spread out than Chicago or Boston (or Mpls).
I've been to Reno a few times; once as a child with my parents, once as a young man, and once with my wife. It's a small town that has casinos, and really not much else.
I highly recommend Dragon*Con. 4 hotels, all within one block of each other. It's a great group of people and very appreciative of authors in attendance.

I've lived in Reno/Sparks area almost all my life. The weather is rarely extreme. We are at about 4400 feet, little to no humidity. Nothing like Vegas. There is so much to do so close, too. Like others have said, Lake Tahoe, Donner Lake, even Pyramid Lake if you're into alkali. Lots of great hiking trails, mountain biking, etc.

Stoked that this will be in Reno, my hometown. Hope to get my copy of A Dance with Dragons autographed...
comments.subject: Reno!

comments.article: Eh? Montreal is eminently walkable and, if need be, the Metro is a convenient way to get around too. Probably won't make it though...

I can't go to either but I am keeping tabs on Mr. Martin's next trip to the Midwest for sure.

As for unhappy, bitter trolls, read another book man, or at least keep your vitriol to yourself. Heck, read books that GRRM published years ago, like Fevre Dream or Armageddon Rag, that helped build his name, or check out the massive and massively entertaining Dreamsongs volumes if you haven't. Or read stuff he likes even, like The Lies of Locke Lamora (a real charmer despite my best efforts not to be swayed).

But don't come onto this blog to nitpick what cons he goes to or whatever else he does with his free time, becuase then you're part of the problem.

George, I love your blog and love that you take the time to share your thoughts on football, politics, conventions, break-ins, cool collectibles, and even your battle to get people their calendars. Don't let the negative folks get you down. I'm sure most readers are fans like myself who care about more in life than pestering authors to rush books they're interested in.

The post by Parris made me smile. Good stuff.
comments.subject: Con

comments.article: Darn...Seattle's only 2 hours from where I live.  Reno is a nice place.  I've been there once.  Might be worth the 18 hour drive to go down there in 2011 for a chance to see George.

I shot a man in Reno...

Looking forward to 2010, it's a little closer. It'll be my first con and, after recently re-watching Galaxy Quest, feel I should go in disguise, not costume.
Didn't see this!  Oops!
Off topic--but I'm very excited to hear about a publication date from your publisher.  I thought that we were going to hear it from you first?  It would be great to have a confirmation.
comments.subject: Dance with Dragons?

comments.article:
Consider this an anti-confirmation.

You WILL hear it from me first.

As I have said before, numerous times, believe nothing you hear from any other source.
comments.subject: Re: Dance with Dragons?

comments.article: Shot a man in Reno, once.  This must have been before they had casinos, because it was purely for the entertainment value.  ;)
